Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Lateral Oblique Closing Wedge Osteotomy for Cubitus Varus in Adults

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a single orthopedic center. Twelve adult patients (aged 31–48 years) with cubitus varus deformity were randomly assigned to receive either the intervention or standard care.

Participants.evidence: Twelve adult patients (aged 31–48 years) with cubitus varus deformity were randomly assigned to receive either the intervention or standard care.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either the intervention or standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of a lateral oblique closing wedge osteotomy with lag screw fixation and early motion in adults with cubitus varus deformity.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the improvement in the humerus-elbow-wrist angle, measured over a minimum follow-up of 15 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Twelve patients were randomised, and all were included in the analysis, which followed an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The humerus-elbow-wrist angle improved from −23.3° to 8° (p < 0.002), with a mean gain of 29.6°.
